contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person | name = Anthony Blaxland Stransham | image = Anthony Blaxland Stransham.jpg | caption = | birth_date = 22 December 1805 | death_date = October 1900 | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | birth_place = | death_place = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | allegiance = {{flagicon|UK}} [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] | branch = [[Royal Marines]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = [[Battle of Navarino]],<br />[[First Opium War|First Anglo-Chinese War]],<br />[[Crimean War]] | battles_label = | awards = [[Order of the Bath|KCB]], [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] | relations = | laterwork = }} [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] '''Sir Anthony Blaxland Stransham''', [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] (22 December 1805 â€“ October 1900), was a British military officer. ==Background== Stransham was the son of Lt. Col. Anthony Stransham of the Royal Marines and grandson of Major Samuel Stransham of the Royal Marines, who planted the British flag on the [[Falkland Islands]], claiming it for [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]]. ==Military career== Stransham entered the [[Royal Marines]] on 1 January 1823. Four years after entering the service, he was present as a [[Subaltern]] at the [[Battle of Navarino]] on 20 October 1827. Stransham led the [[Royal Marines]] during the attack on the City of [[Guangzhou|Canton]] in the [[First Opium War]] in 1841.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=19984|supp=|startpage=1429|date=3 June 1841|accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> He was wounded and was promoted to Captain.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=20071|supp=|startpage=402|date=15 February 1842|accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> He was awarded the [[Baltic Medal]], having been with [[Charles John Napier]] in 1854. From 1862 to 1867, General Stransham was Inspector-General of the Royal Marines.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=23210|supp=|startpage=319|date=16 January 1867|accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> Later in his career, as a General, the "Grand Old Man of the Army" became a [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]].<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=26947|supp=|startpage=1681|date=14 March 1898|accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> He saw active service for over 53 years, retiring with the rank of [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] on 24 December 1875.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=24286|supp=|startpage=256|date=21 January 1876|accessdate=5 April 2010}}</ref> == References == {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Stransham, Anthony Blaxland | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = British general | DATE OF BIRTH =22 December 1805 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1900 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stransham, Anthony Blaxland}} [[Category:1805 births]] [[Category:1900 deaths]] [[Category:British military personnel of the First Opium War]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:People of the Greek War of Independence]] [[Category:Royal Marines generals]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Crimean War]]
